etymologies: late Middle English (denoting the action of bearing hardship, or the ability to bear pain and hardship): via Old French from Latin tolerantia, from tolerare (see tolerate)

definitions: the ability or willingness to tolerate something, in particular the existence of opinions or behavior that one does not necessarily agree with
shortDefinitions: ability or willingness to tolerate existence of opinions or behaviour that one dislikes or disagrees with

definitions: the capacity to endure continued subjection to something, especially a drug, transplant, antigen, or environmental conditions, without adverse reaction

examples.text: the desert camel shows the greatest tolerance to dehydration
various species of diatoms display different tolerances to acid
species were grouped according to pollution tolerance

shortDefinitions: capacity to endure continued subjection to something such as drug

definitions: diminution in the body's response to a drug after continued use

examples.text: the body's tolerance to Ecstasy builds up very quickly

shortDefinitions: diminution in body's response to drug after continued use

definitions: an allowable amount of variation of a specified quantity, especially in the dimensions of a machine or part

examples.text: 250 parts in his cars were made to tolerances of one thousandth of an inch

shortDefinitions: allowable amount of variation of specified quantity
